content.content: 1011×471 199 KB   The Situation The Makerdao.com blog is an unused resource that can be a valuable asset if appropriately managed. Benefits include but are not limited to;  Access to an established external audience. Better control over Maker’s narrative. Access to a platform where we can reinforce Maker’s brand. Paves the way for inclusion in a larger marketing funnel. Increase overall exposure. Improves ties with the extended community of interested people. New channel for  Product Releases Product Notices Monthly Financial Reports Annual Financial Reports One-off thought pieces Press Releases     image1795×620 71.8 KB  GovComms planned on submitting a MIP60 - Intangible Asset Agreement Modification of Management proposal to step in as the blog’s content manager. However, with the failing of SP63, preventing a public relations specialist hire, and our ongoing mandate redesign, that moves away from externally focused communications, we are no longer the best option for blog management. We do not believe it’s in the DAO’s best interest to leave the blog unused. We are willing to share our draft MIP with anyone interested in pursuing the role. We are bringing this to the community’s attention because this matter is blocked from progressing. The options, as we see them, are:   Leave the blog unused. The status quo carries on until the stars line up.   Onboard a marketing CU who will eventually manage the blog. Conceptually, this is the best option. The caveat is the amount of time it will take for such a team to come about; Minimum, six months, maximum, unlimited.   Persuade Growth or Brand to take on this responsibility. May require the adjustment of mandate or budget.   Persuade GovComms to take on this responsibility. May require the adjustment of mandate or budget.       Which course of action do you believe is appropriate for the blog?  Leave the blog unused Onboard a marketing CU who will eventually manage the blog Persuade Growth or Brand to take on this responsibility Persuade GovComms to take on this responsibility Abstain     0 voters       Our View We believe the right course of action is to wait for a proper marketing team. Running the blog should require professional public relations oversight, which the DAO currently has no capacity for. The teams who currently come closest are the Growth CU and the incubating Brand CU. However, the responsibility seems out of scope for both in their current forms.

I understand GovComms’ position when stating that a Marketing team would be the most suited to manage this resource. Despite this, I believe there is already plenty of specialized content being generated by CUs and the community in general, content that could be quickly put to use in this situation. Members from all over the world spark conversations and bring to the table all kinds of relevant news concerning MakerDAO. Regarding CUs, GovComms, for example, produces many summaries and tailored recaps of what is transpiring within the community every week. Even daily, I’d dare to say. Why not select a few, design a series of recurrent categories for the Blog, and put this content out there? It could be a wonderful opportunity to let all this hard work shine for a broader audience. Surely we could think of this first step at reclaiming the Blog as a placeholder until we arrive at the desired destination. I also understand this would mean loading more work to teams that are probably functioning at the top of their capacity, and, given the characteristics of the crisis the DAO–everyone–is navigating, I tend to suspect there won’t be proper compensation for said load. Sad, yes. Understandable too. Debatable? Of course. In favor of what I said above, utilizing what is already being produced with excellent quality by our CUs and community could be a good medium. As a member of the community and occasional contributor, I trust GovComms could take on such a task. But Growth is an apt candidate as well. It depends on the direction we are going for, I suppose. Is it only about communicating clearly and effectively? Then GovComms, sure. Is it about adoption and the generation of opportunities? It should be Growth. Do we want both? Why not work together!

I refrain for the simple fact that I don’t know the current workload of the CUs, we can see reports and everything they notify but behind that there is a team and the stress overload makes the team work worse. We have an excess of information, for example, the Twitter account in both English and Spanish gives good quality information, the forum community gives a lot of quality information, the two candidates are good but before demanding that they carry out the task we should check if they have the enough space to enter that task on your work schedule. I don’t want to eliminate the blog, it’s a more organized way of giving information, but the only way is to make that blog address all types of audience regardless of language, and that requires a lot of administrative work. We will be able to use Twitter while the DAO is organized, and use that medium more, thus avoiding the work overload of the CU.

First, does anyone actually want to run the blog?  A good blog is going to be run by someone who wants to do it, and would take very little time or experience to jump into. If we have to “persuade” someone to do it, the work won’t be as good. We should start by just finding someone interested in spending a few hours a week writing up posts. Then if it gains traction, we can scale up and invest into it. The initial attempt should not require budget adjustments or new CUs.     Moi:  but the only way is to make that blog address all types of audience regardless of language, and that requires a lot of administrative work.   This feels like putting the cart behind the horse. Most likely, the blog will have few readers and the project won’t justify such investment. Start small. Find someone who wants to manage the blog and give a small stipend as compensation. Then if it gains traction we can discuss adding budgets and translating into other languages.

You are absolutely right in what you say, that is why I refrained, we cannot give a job that does not have a 100% probability of success to CU that already have enough work. Another option would be “Use an active member in the community who is solely responsible for the blog” If the blog succeeds because the budget is increased as you say, in the meantime it is a risky move and they add more work unnecessarily.

The most important part which make a blog successful is regularity. Regular blog posts will generate new traffic, make it found online and get more readers. But regularity comes with interest.     CodeKnight:  finding someone interested in spending a few hours a week writing up posts   So finding someone interested in spending a few hours a week writing up posts, is going be a better option.

I mostly disagree with your suggestion.     CodeKnight:  First, does anyone actually want to run the blog?   This doesn’t matter. The blog is an asset to the DAO in its own right and the DAO should squeeze as much value out of it as possible. Not doing so is giving back all the advantage and momentum built up by the Maker Foundation. If the DAO wants to get that value it will find and fund someone to operate it. The real question is “by what means”     CodeKnight:  We should start by just finding someone interested in spending a few hours a week writing up posts. Then if it gains traction, we can scale up and invest into it. The initial attempt should not require budget adjustments or new CUs.   I advise against this approach. Hiring a lone uncommitted contributor is a recipe for disaster. Who manages them? Who quality checks them? What’s their level of commitment? What posts are they writing? What’s their plan for content? etc. Even hiring a contributor for a few hours of writing a week is not enough, there’s a lot more that goes into it. In my view, this would require a full-time hire at a minimum because of the level of execution the DAO should expect – The foundation had two people running the blog as their FULL-TIME JOBS(Granted they also triaged media inquiries and contributed to PR strategy) with several other people contributing in a limited capacity. The blog is not an “if it gains traction” kind of thing. It has a large existing readership that’s waiting to be rekindled. There is 0 doubt in my mind that this investment would have a high impact and lots of traction. However, the problem is the setup and additional expense. I reiterate my view; The blog is a key piece of our external communications toolkit. A marketing team will be sorely needed as our protocol comes out with more and more products. I think this needs to be handled with a professional PR/Marketing approach.

If the blog is going to require 1-2 full time hires just to start, then I would be against it. This seems to be a recurring issue with marketing in Maker. Everything requires a very high amount of time and money to start, while other protocols are getting better marketing with far less spending.
CodeKnight:  while other protocols are getting better marketing with far less spending.   Can you provide some examples?

I support a small part regarding your opinion, I still insist on not placing CU to manage the blog since they have enough work, adding another role to some CU is restructuring their plans, if two people could be placed to manage full time, Why not post active forum users? If it is for hiring, we must make sure that the path that the blog takes could give us a high probability of success. If it is hired, we must give them some requirements to develop a budget in the blog administrators, since if we do not achieve the objective we will have wasted time and budget
